Message Body: Berkeley, California (Wednesday, October 13, 2021)—On October 6, 2021, at 5:46 pm, the University of California Police Department (UCPD) received a report of a motor scooter theft from the Recreational Sports Facility, on the UC Berkeley campus. A UCPD officer conducted a preliminary investigation and developed a lead on a possible suspect. (Since the start of the semester, UCPD has seen an increasing trend in the number of motor scooter thefts on campus.) On October 7, at 5:36pm, the UCPD officer noticed the theft suspect had returned to Spieker Plaza, on the UC Berkeley campus. During a subsequent investigation, the suspect was found to be in possession of other people's credit cards, narcotics, brass knuckles, bear spray and burglary tools. The suspect was arrested for a parole warrant and on suspicion of various theft and weapons charges.
Message Title: Community Message - SUSPECTS CHARGED IN MOTOR SCOOTER THEFT AND THEFT OF ELECTRONICS

 Community Advisory: Electric Scooter Thefts 
 With the start of the Spring semester, we are once again seeing an increase in the theft of electric scooters on and near campus. Scooters are considered motor vehicles and need to be secured to prevent theft. 
 Here are some precautions you can take to deter theft:
 -Always lock up your scooter. -Use a high quality U-lock affixed between the scooter stem and the deck to secure the frame to the bike rack. 
 -Leave your scooter in a visible, well-lighted area.
 -When possible, do not leave scooters out overnight or for extended periods. 
 -Keep a record of your serial number in case of theft.

The caller demands money be wired to an overseas bank account, defrauding victims of money. 
 These scammers are using a technique referred to as “caller-ID spoofing.” This is the practice of causing the intended victims’ telephone network to show that the call came from somewhere other than its true origination.  Community Advisory: Electric Scooter Thefts 
 With the start of the semester, we are once again seeing an increase in the theft of electric scooters on and near campus. Scooters are considered motor vehicles and need to be secured to prevent theft. 
 Here are some precautions you can take to deter theft:
 -Always lock up your scooter. -Use a high quality U-lock affixed between the scooter stem and the deck to secure the frame to the bike rack. 
 -Leave your scooter in a visible, well-lighted area.
 -When possible, do not leave scooters out overnight or for extended periods. 
 -Keep a record of your serial number in case of theft.

Community Advisory: With the start of the Fall semester, we are once again seeing an increase in the theft of electric scooters on and near campus. Scooters are considered motor vehicles and need to be secured to prevent theft.
Here are some precautions you can take to deter theft: -Always lock up your scooter.
-Use a high quality U-lock affixed between the scooter stem and the deck to secure the frame to the bike rack. -Leave your scooter in a visible, well-lighted area. -When possible, do not leave scooters out overnight or for extended periods.
